Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Bering Glacier Surge--Observation, Analysis and Parameterization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are provided to observe, document and analyze the current surge of Bering Glacier and derive parameters that capture deformation characteristics during surge stages and provide information that may facilitate mechanical modeling of fast glacier movement. Observations will include aerial GPS, video and photographic data, fixed laser profilometry and time-sequenced satellite imagery. Analysis of the surge propagation will employ an automated spatial-statistical/connectionist approach developed by the PI, this allows derivation of deformation characteristics, as evident in surge crevasse structures from imagery, and linkage of them to ice dynamics.

Glacier surges can have an immediate and detrimental impact on ecosystems situated in their path. Few such surges have been carefully observed and described making it difficult to understand what characteristics of surging glaciers can be expected as typical and what range of variability is realistic to anticipate. This makes long-range management planning and risk assessment for such systems difficult. The proposed research will contribute to the resolution of this issue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding fast-flowing glaciers and accelerations in ice flow is critical to understanding changes in the cryosphere and ultimately changes in sea level.  According to the Fifth Assessment Report (AR5) of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC, 2013), glacial acceleration is the largest source of uncertainty in assessment of  sea-level rise in the current realm of climatic warming. Surging is one of only four types of glacial accelerations and the one that has seen the least amount of research. In that they suddenly accelerate and advance in a quasi-cyclic and unpredictable pattern, surge-type glaciers are a counterpoint to the seemingly omnipresent retreat in the cryosphere. The current surge of the Bering-Bagley Glacier System in Alaska (BBGS) provided a rare opportunity to observe and analyze a surge of a large and complex glacier system. Bering Glacier, with Bagley IceValley, is the largest temperate  surge-type glacier on Earth, located in an environment that is a little warmer than most of Greenland, and the largest ice mass outside of the Greenland and Antarctic ice sheets. The BBGS has been surging since 2011 and the surge continues to expand in the Bagley Ice Valley (as of summer 2014).

Intellectual Merit.
The Bering Glacier RAPID was funded by the National Science Foundation to study the current surge of Alaska's largest and longest glacier system, Bering Glacier and Bagley Ice Valley, which started in 2011. A surge is an acceleration of a glacier to typically 10-100 times its normal velocity, it occurs quasi-cyclic every 25 years (for Bering) [Figures 1-3].  A surge is also a natural catastrophe that impacts the ecological system in the area surrounding the glacier. A surge includes many different dynamic phases which can last weeks to months.

The size and complexity of the BBGS requires remote-sensing and aerial observations, combined with automated mathematical data analysis, to analyze the ice-dynamic and hydrologic processes involved. The research team conducted four observation campaigns in a total of 11 weeks, in fall 2011, summer and fall 2012 and summer 2013 [Fig. 4]. Observations include laser altimetry, video imagery, GPS data and photographic image data.  The observational activities far exceeded the proposed goals. The laser altimeter data provided critical information on the third dimension of the surge (elevation). Combing laser altimeter and imagery, we were able to calculate elevation change and characterize the surge progression. Analyses were complemented by satellite altimeter data from the European Space Agnecy's CryoSat-2, airborne altimeter data from NASA's Operation IceBridge and satellite image data collected by DigitalGlobe (available to our project through Polar Geospatial Center, University of Minnesota).

To link observations and future modeling of physical processes, the project has taken an approach that includes application of automated spatial statistical-connectionist classification of deformation characteristics as evident in crevasse patterns [Figs. 5, 6]. The resultant parameterizations  enable mapping of ice-dynamic provinces and are expected to facilitate modeling of fast glacier movement [Fig.7]. The mathematical approach taken by this project provides a new way to link observations and numerical experiments, which is one of the key challenges in advancing glaciology. Furthermore the surge of the Bering Bagley system allowed to  learn about processes involved in glacier surging in general and to investigate  physical processes associated with certain forms glacial acceleration as may occur in the margin of the Greenland ice sheet.
